While simulated soil moisture quantitatively differs between models, the models show a robust qualitative agreement on its strong effect on NBP ( Fig. 1). Across models, soil moisture variability and trends in mean moisture state strongly reduce the land carbon sink, with their combined effect ( NBP ( SMVAR) + ( NBP ( TREND) ) being of the same order of magnitude as the land sink (estimated from the CTL runs, ( NBP ( LAND) ) ( Fig. 1). It should be noted that in contrast to the Global Carbon Budget
1 , the land sink term defined by NBP includes emissions from land use and land cover change (LULC).
